awd_abstract_narration:
In the 1960s mathematician Robert Langlands developed a vision connecting two apparently disparate fields of mathematics, number theory and representation theory. This work led to what is now known as the Langlands program, which reveals a web of deep and as yet only partially understood connections between number theory, representation theory, geometry, and mathematical physics. This project aims to answer core questions of the Langlands program revolving around the so-called functoriality conjecture, in a generalized setting known as the relative Langlands program. 
 
The relative Langlands program replaces reductive groups by more general homogeneous spaces, aiming to understand their local and automorphic spectra. A basic tool is the relative trace formula, a generalization of the Arthur-Selberg trace formula, which has still not been fully developed. The project aims to establish new types of comparisons between relative trace formulas that would simultaneously address the questions of relative functoriality, and of conjectural relations between periods of automorphic forms and L-functions. The two main goals of the project are: (1) the development of the technical basis for such comparisons, including a general relative trace formula, and (2) the development of a local-to-global strategy for the comparison of trace formulas, as in endoscopy, but with scalar transfer factors replaced by more general transfer operators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project started as NSF award 1801429 while the PI was at Rutgers University, and continued as NSF award 1939672, after the PI moved to Johns Hopkins University.

The award produced results in two different directions, both of which belong to the Langlands program. The Langlands program, one of the most central areas of current research within and beyond number theory, aims to relate questions of arithmetic, such as the solutions of diophantine equations, to the study of operators on arithmetic manifolds. The latter are geometric objects with large, continuous (Lie) groups of symmetry, and one is interested in studying automorphic forms, which are eigenfunctions of certain operators afforded by those symmetries. This project studied the question of relating automorphic forms on different such manifolds (a conjecture that goes by the name of functoriality), as well as the question of understanding how to represent L-functions – fundamental invariants of the automorphic forms with applications to arithmetic – in terms of certain integrals (called periods) of automorphic forms.

On the question of functoriality, which the PI is viewing in the broader context of the "relative" Langlands program, the project further developed a novel technique of comparing automorphic representations attached to different groups and spaces, combining Langlands' ideas "beyond endoscopy" with new ideas related to the relative trace formula – a method introduced by Jacquet to study periods of automorphic forms. The PI was able to show, for spaces of rank one, that a very uniform theory of transfer operators (or "functoriality kernels") exists, and to compute related transfer operators in a range of other settings. This opens the way for investigations in higher rank, in order to develop a novel paradigm of comparisons of trace formulas that will give rise to the proof of the functoriality conjecture.

On the question of relations between periods and L-functions, the PI undertook collaborative work with Jonathan Wang, on one hand, and with Ben-Zvi and Venkatesh, on the other, to understand which L-functions are associated to which period. In the work with Wang, they managed to calculate the local L-functions associated to special functions ("IC functions") that reflect the singularities of arc spaces of varieties, more precisely of spherical varieties with full dual group. This generalized prior work of the author (partly with Bouthier and Ngô), and proved some conjectures that the PI formulated about a decade earlier. In the work with Ben-Zvi and Venkatesh, which is ongoing, they proposed a categorification of this relation between periods and L-functions, viewing both as quantizations of suitable Hamiltonian manifolds, in a way that is related to ideas of Kapustin, Witten, and Gaiotto for the meaning of Langlands duality in quantum field theory.

In addition to these advances in research, the project had an impact on the broader number theory community, with the organization of numerous conferences, seminars series, and the development of an electronic reference site, the Automorphic Project, on the topic of automorphic representations. Notably, the award helped fund annual conferences in number theory for junior mathematicians (at the last year of their PhD or shortly thereafter), and the PI co-organized one a series of online seminars on automorphic representations, which helped keep the community of researchers connected during the COVID pandemic.
